Hearty, meaty, and packed with warm spices.

Serves6 to 8

Prep30 minutes

Cook2 hours 30 minutes

We independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.

Moussaka, the unofficial national dish of Greece, is synonymous with special occasions — think Christmas, Easter, Sunday church meals, birthdays, or even a son or daughter returning home to see their family. It has a firm place in the hearts of Greeks everywhere for good reason; it’s the definition of comfort food. Hearty, meaty, and packed with warm spices, it’s a dish every home cook should have in their arsenal, and one you should share with loved ones whatever the occasion.

Moussaka has a long, winding history. There are versions of the dish stretching across Middle Eastern and Mediterranean countries, all with different preparations. In the mainstream culinary consciousness, however, it’s largely seen as a Greek invention. Sometime in the 1920s, Greek chef and cookbook author Nikolas Tselementes created the famous version of moussaka that we know today — potato, eggplant, meat mince, and creamy bechamel sauce layered and baked in an oven like a casserole. 

I spoke with many Greek friends, who in turn contacted their mothers and grandmothers for old family recipes. Naturally, they’re all different. Some swear by nutmeg, while others protest it. Eggplant is of, course, a constant. Lamb and beef are used interchangeably or in tandem. Cloves, all spice, and bay leaves all come and go throughout various recipes. Cinnamon sticks, however, are used consistently, and while some say the inclusion of potatoes isn’t traditional, they undeniably add more body and sustenance.

When it comes to moussaka, I find it’s best to go big or go home. Plan on moussaka being the centerpiece to a family gathering or small dinner party. I put my own, small mark on this moussaka recipe by adding fresh oregano and parsley to the meat mix. Feel free to experiment, but in the end, it’s important to remain loyal to the dish’s inherent warmth. Bay leaves, cinnamon, herbs, tender potatoes, eggplant, lamb, and béchamel is as cozy as it gets.

Why You’ll Love It

  • No frying necessary! Baking the eggplant and potatoes lets you take more work off your plate.
  • It tastes luxurious. The béchamel sauce includes egg yolks, a step which many Greek grandmothers don’t skip. The egg yolks enhance the dish’s luxurious feel. 

Key Ingredients in Moussaka

  • Ground lamb and ground beef: Using a combination makes for a robust flavor.
  • Fresh oregano and fresh parsley: These herbs infuse a lovely bit of earthiness into the meat sauce.
  • Bay leaf, cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg: Each spice adds sweet, nutty warmth to this dish.
  • Egg yolks: Enriches the béchamel sauce considerably for a luxurious texture.
  • Pecorino Romano: Traditionally, kefalotryi, a Greek cheese made from sheep’s milk, is used in moussaka. I couldn’t find any, so I instead opted for Pecorino — another sheep’s milk cheese that’s big on flavor. This funky, pungent cheese enhances the moussaka’s flavor profile. 

How to Make Moussaka

  1. Bake the eggplant and potatoes. Slice both vegetables, season with salt, pepper, and olive oil, then bake them in a 400°F oven until lightly browned.
  2. Build the meat sauce. In a large Dutch oven, brown the lamb and beef. Next, cook the onion, garlic, and herbs. Add tomato paste, reduce the white wine, the browned meat, meat back canned tomatoes, and spices. Cook until the sauce thickens and the tomatoes lose their harsh acidity. 
  3. Make the béchamel. Make a roux, then slowly whisk in the milk, stirring often to make sure all clumps of flour dissolve. Bring to a simmer, and cook until the sauce has thickened. Add the salt, pepper, Pecorino Romano, and nutmeg, and whisk. Place the béchamel in a large metal bowl and cover tightly with plastic wrap for 20 minutes. Next, whisk the 4 egg yolks into the béchamel sauce and cover again.
  4. Build the moussaka. Place the cooked potatoes in a layer on the bottom of a 9×13 baking dish. Next, add a layer of eggplant. Using both hands, press down to compact the vegetables. Pour the meat sauce over the vegetables, and use a rubber spatula to even it. Pour the béchamel sauce over the meat sauce, and do the same. Sprinkle with more Pecorino Romano, and cook in a 375°F oven until the top is browned.
  5. Rest. Let the moussaka rest for at least 30 minutes before serving, but really, you want to let it sit more like an hour. It’s even better the next day.

Helpful Swaps

  • If unavailable, ground beef may easily be substituted for ground lamb. 
  • Ground cinnamon and dry oregano may be substituted for cinnamon sticks and fresh oregano, though I personally don’t recommend it.
  • One (28-ounce) can whole peeled tomatoes and their juices, blended in a food processor until puréed, can be used in place of the crushed tomatoes.

Storage and Make-Ahead Tips 

  • You may cook the moussaka’s eggplant, potatoes, and meat sauce a day in advance. Layer them in a 9×13-inch baking dish, cover with plastic wrap, and take it out of the fridge the next day when you plan on making the béchamel to finish the casserole.
  • Leftovers can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 4 days, or frozen for up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in the refrigerator before reheating.

What to Serve With Moussaka

Moussaka is deliciously rich, warm, and hearty. Of course it works well with a salad (like horiatiki), but I would also consider serving it with briny, Castlevetrano olives and a glass of champagne. The acidic nature of both pairs excellently with moussaka.

Comments

Hearty, meaty, and packed with warm spices.

Nutritional Info

Ingredients

For the eggplant and potatoes:

  • 2 1/2 pounds

    Yukon Gold potatoes, sliced 1/4-inch thick

  • 2 tablespoons

    olive oil, divided

  • 2 teaspoons

    kosher salt, divided, plus more as needed

  • Freshly ground black pepper

  • 2 1/2 pounds

    globe eggplants, sliced crosswise 1/2-inch thick

For the meat sauce:

  • 2 tablespoons

    olive oil

  • 1 pound

    ground beef, preferably 20% fat

  • 1 pound

    ground lamb

  • 2 1/2 teaspoons

    kosher salt, divided, plus more as needed

  • Freshly ground black pepper

  • 2

    medium sweet or yellow onions, diced (about 3 cups)

  • 6 cloves

    garlic, minced

  • 1 tablespoon

    coarsely chopped fresh parsley leaves, plus more for garnish (optional)

  • 1 tablespoon

    coarsely chopped fresh oregano leaves, plus more for garnish

  • 1/4 cup

    tomato paste

  • 1 cup

    dry white wine

  • 1 (28-ounce) can

    crushed tomatoes

  • 2

    dried bay leaves

  • 2

    whole cloves

  • 1

    (about 3-inch) cinnamon stick, broken in half

For the béchamel sauce and layering:

  • 8 tablespoons

    unsalted butter

  • 2/3 cup

    all-purpose flour

  • 4 cups

    (1 quart) whole milk

  • 1 cup

    freshly grated Pecorino Romano cheese (about 3 ounces), divided

  • 1/2 teaspoon

    kosher salt, plus more as needed

  • 1/2 teaspoon

    freshly grated nutmeg

  • 1/4 teaspoon

    freshly ground black pepper

  • 4

    large egg yolks

Roast the eggplant and potatoes:

  1. Arrange 2 racks to divide the oven into thirds and heat the oven to 400ºF. Place 2 1/2 pounds sliced Yukon Gold potatoes on a rimmed baking sheet. Drizzle with 1 of the tablespoon olive oil and season with 1 teaspoon of the kosher salt and a few grinds of black pepper. Toss to coat and arrange into a single layer. Repeat tossing and arranging 2 1/2 pounds sliced eggplant, 1 tablespoon olive oil, 1 teaspoon kosher salt, and black pepper together on a second baking sheet.

  2. Bake the eggplant on the upper rack and the potatoes on the lower rack for 20 minutes. Flip the eggplant and potato slices, return to the oven onto the same racks, and bake until lightly browned, 15 to 20 minutes more. Meanwhile, make the meat filling.

Make the meat sauce:

  1. Heat 2 tablespoons olive oil in a pot or Dutch oven over medium heat until shimmering. Add 1 pound ground beef, 1 teaspoon of the kosher salt, and a few grinds of black pepper. Cook, breaking up the meat into small pieces, until browned and cooked through, 5 to 7 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer to a large bowl.

  2. Add 1 pound ground lamb, 1 teaspoon of the kosher salt, and a few grinds of black pepper. Repeat cooking the meat and transferring to the bowl.

  3. Add 2 diced medium sweet onions, 6 minced garlic cloves, 1 tablespoon coarsely chopped fresh parsley leaves if using, 1 tablespoon coarsely chopped fresh oregano leaves, and the remaining 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt to the pot. Cook, stirring occasionally and scraping up any browned bits from the bottom, until the vegetables are translucent and fragrant, about 5 minutes.

  4. Make a well in the center of the vegetables. Add 1/4 cup tomato paste into the well and let cook undisturbed for 1 minute. Stir into the vegetables. Stir in 1 cup dry white wine and cook until mostly evaporated, 3 to 5 minutes.

  5. Return the meats and any accumulated juices to the pot. Add 1 (28-ounce) can crushed tomatoes, 2 dried bay leaves, 2 whole cloves, and 1 halved (3-inch) cinnamon stick. Stir to combine and bring to a simmer over medium-high heat.

  6. Reduce the heat to low and cook, stirring occasionally, until the sauce is darkened in color, thickened, and the tomatoes are no longer acidic and the flavors meld, 30 to 40 minutes. Taste and season with more kosher salt as needed. Meanwhile, make the béchamel sauce.

Make the béchamel sauce:

  1. Melt 1 stick unsalted butter in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Whisk in 2/3 cup all-purpose flour and cook, whisking often, for about 1 1/2 minutes to cook the floury taste out.

  2. While constantly whisking, slowly pour in 4 cups whole milk. Whisk until smooth and cook, whisking often, until simmering. Reduce the heat to medium-low and cook, whisking often, until thickened enough to coat the back of a spoon, about 5 minutes.

  3. Whisk in 1/2 cup of the grated Pecorino Romano cheese, 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt, 1/2 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg, and 1/4 teaspoon black pepper. Taste and season with more kosher salt as needed. Transfer to a heatproof bowl and cover tightly with plastic wrap. Let cool for about 20 minutes. Uncover and whisk in 4 large egg yolks. Cover again.

Assemble and bake the moussaka:

  1. Reduce the oven temperature to 375ºF.

  2. Taste the potatoes and eggplant and season with kosher salt as needed — they should be well seasoned. Arrange the potato slices in a broiler-safe 9x13-inch baking dish in an even layer. They can overlap. Layer the eggplant on top of the potatoes. Use your hands and press down on the vegetables to compact slightly.

  3. Remove the cinnamon stick pieces, bay leaves, and cloves from the meat sauce and discard. Spread the meat sauce evenly over the vegetables. Dollop the béchamel sauce over the meat sauce and spread into an even layer. Sprinkle with the remaining 1/2 cup grated Pecorino Romano.

  4. Bake until the top is browned, about 45 minutes. If you’d like the top to be more deeply browned, turn on the broiler and broil as needed. Let cool for at least 30 minutes before serving so the layers firm up. Garnish with more chopped parsley and oregano if desired.

Recipe Notes

Canned tomatoes: 1 (28-ounce) can whole peeled tomatoes and their juices, blended in a food processor until puréed, can be used in place of the crushed tomatoes.

General tips: If you don’t feel like picking out the bay leaves, cloves, and cinnamon stick pieces out of the sauce, tie them up in cheesecloth and kitchen twine before cooking so they will be easier to remove.

Storage: Leftovers can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 4 days, or frozen for up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in the refrigerator before reheating.
